content:
I don't have personal experience but i can describe the general migration patterns of humpback whales based on research. humpback whales are famous for their long-distance migrations that typically occur over the course of several months. these massive cetaceans travel between their breeding and feeding grounds in oceans all around the world. 

humpback whales found in the north pacific generally spend their summers feeding in cool, nutrient-rich waters near the poles and migrate in winter to warm, tropical waters near hawaii, mexico or central america to mate and give birth. in contrast, humpbacks in the southern hemisphere feed in the antarctic waters in summer and migrate north towards the tropics to breed from june to september. 

the migration distances can be thousands of kilometers. the whales travel in groups or individually, following well-defined migration routes and show fidelity to their breeding and feeding grounds, with some individuals returning to the same areas year after year. they may travel at speeds of up to 15 kilometers per hour but average around 2-5 kilometers per hour. their migration patterns depend on factors such as the location of food sources, climate, ocean currents, and breeding behavior.
